dt.t: Sacrifice, renunciation, {wi}asceticism{/wi}, fasting, returning again to God … : these are inclinations fueled as much by instinct as by religious idealism.
Crossing the Atlantic in a small sailboat is an exercise in {wi}asceticism{/wi}, a test of what the human psyche can do without.
His neatly trimmed white beard and runner's physique suggest the {wi}asceticism{/wi} of a mathematics professor, while his questioning mind signals a mistrust of surface impressions.

In contrast to the chaste {wi}asceticism{/wi} of earlier modernist office towers, the AT&T Building incorporated traditional symbols of imperial power (Roman vaults and arches), prestige (a Chippendale-inspired silhouette), and old money (a huge golden statue in the lobby, which once stood on top of the old AT&T Building).

shortdef: the practice of strict self-denial as a measure of personal and especially spiritual discipline : the condition, practice, or mode of life of an ascetic : rigorous abstention from self-indulgence
austerity in appearance, manner, or attitude
